title: Frede Jensen (philologist)
text:
Frede Jensen, <a href="Doctorate">Ph.D.</a>, (February 17, 1926 - September 13, 2008) was a 20th-century, <a href="Danish%20people">Danish</a>-born <a href="Romance%20languages">Romance</a> <a href="philologist">philologist</a>, <a href="author">author</a>, and <a href="Professorship">professor</a> of <a href="French%20language">French</a>. Author of 17 books and over 60 articles, he was widely respected by the <a href="Romance%20languages">romance</a> <a href="philology">philology</a> community and recognized as an expert in the field. He is highly esteemed for his detailed and thorough publications on the grammar of <a href="Old%20Occitan">Old Occitan</a> (also referred to as <a href="Proven%C3%A7al%20dialect">Provençal</a>) and has been referred to endearingly as "the '<a href="Grevisse">Grevisse</a>' of old <a href="Occitan">Occitan</a>". Jensen is also considered an expert on <a href="Sicilian%20poetry">Sicilian poetry</a>. His English translation and analysis of previously untranslated <a href="Sicilian%20language">Sicilian</a> poems have been honorably referred to as one of the <a href="codex%20optimus">codices optimi</a> on the subject, dating from <a href="Dante">Dante</a> forward.
An extraordinary <a href="linguist">linguist</a>, Jensen was fluent in eight languages with a remarkable command of <a href="medieval">medieval</a>/<a href="Classical%20antiquity">ancient</a> <a href="Romance%20languages">Romance languages</a>. His publications include
works on <a href="Vulgar%20Latin">vulgar</a> and classical <a href="Latin">Latin</a>, old <a href="Italian%20Language">Italian</a>, old <a href="Spanish%20Language">Spanish</a>, <a href="medieval">medieval</a> <a href="Occitan">Occitan</a>, old <a href="French%20Language">French</a>, and old <a href="Portuguese%20Language">Portuguese</a>.
Life.
Frede Jensen was born on February 17, 1926 to Hans Jensen and Jenny Kirstine Martinusen in <a href="Taarup">Taarup</a>, <a href="Auning">Auning county</a>, in the <a href="Midtjylland">Midtjylland</a> region of <a href="Denmark">Denmark</a>. He spent his first years on a sizable family homestead and was raised by his two loving parents. Frede was the second of three children born to the Jensen family. The property was home to a lovely forest where <a href="Oak%20tree">oak</a>, <a href="Pine%20tree">pine</a>, and <a href="Beech%20tree">beech</a> trees grew. These early surroundings were likely the mold where Frede's great sensibility to nature was formed.
The <a href="great%20depression">great depression</a> arrived with its share of sufferings and soon the family had to relocate to a smaller house in the nearby small village of <a href="Trojstrup">Trojstrup</a>. Frede lived there with his family until he graduated from the <a href="Randers%20Stattskole">Randers Stattskole</a> in 1945.
When he was a young teenager, he loved collecting and drying flowers from the countryside. His collection later ended up in the hands of the <a href="University%20of%20Copenhagen%20Botanical%20Garden">Museum of the Botanical Garden of Copenhagen</a>, which they still preserve today.
In 1945, Jensen went to the <a href="University%20of%20copenhagen">University of Copenhagen</a> and completed his <a href="undergraduate%20studies">undergraduate studies</a> in 1949. Jensen then attended the <a href="University%20of%20Grenoble">Université de Grenoble</a> in <a href="France">France</a> on a scholarship where he received a degree in <a href="French%20language">French</a> grammar and <a href="Philology">Philology</a> (Certificat de Grammaire et de Philologie Francaises) in 1950.
While in <a href="Grenoble">Grenoble</a> he joined a <a href="mountaineering">mountaineering</a> club. For him it was the door opened to the undulating slopes of <a href="wildflower">wildflower</a>s, before setting his sights on higher summits later in his life.
Jensen returned to <a href="Denmark">Denmark</a> to serve his <a href="Compulsory%20military%20service">mandatory 9-month military service</a> from 1950 to 1951 where he served as a <a href="telex">telex</a> operator.
Jensen then returned to the <a href="University%20of%20copenhagen">University of Copenhagen</a> where he received his <a href="master%27s%20degree">master's degree</a>, with distinction, in 1953 in <a href="French%20language">French</a> with a minor in <a href="English%20language">English</a>.
He spent the summer of 1953 studying at the <a href="University%20of%20Santiago%20de%20Compostela">University of Santiago de Compostela</a> in <a href="Spain">Spain</a>, then went on to attend the <a href="University%20of%20Salamanca">University of Salamanca</a>, <a href="Spain">Spain</a> where he received a <a href="Spanish%20Language">Spanish</a> <a href="Philology">Philology</a> degree in 1955 (Diplomado de Filologia Hispánica). It was here that he met his future wife, whom he later wed in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> in 1968.
In 1956, Jensen moved to <a href="Los%20Angeles">Los Angeles</a>, <a href="California">California</a> in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> on a <a href="Fulbright%20grant">Fulbright grant</a> and subsequently earned his <a href="Doctorate">Ph.D.</a> from <a href="UCLA">U.C.L.A.</a> in 1961, in <a href="Romance%20Languages">Romance Languages</a> and Literatures with an emphasis in <a href="Philology">Philology</a> (<a href="French%20Language">French</a>, <a href="Spanish%20Language">Spanish</a>, and <a href="Italian%20Language">Italian</a>).
Over the next 6 years, Jensen held a number of teaching positions, first at the <a href="University%20of%20Calgary">University of Calgary</a>, <a href="Canada">Canada</a> and then at <a href="UCLA">U.C.L.A.</a>, before settling in <a href="Boulder%20Colorado">Boulder, Colorado</a> to take on a <a href="professorship">professorship</a> position at the <a href="University%20of%20Colorado%20at%20Boulder">University of Colorado</a> in 1967. Jensen was <a href="Professorship">Professor</a> of <a href="French%20Language">French</a> at the <a href="University%20of%20Colorado%20at%20Boulder">University of Colorado at Boulder</a> until his <a href="retirement">retirement</a> on June 19, 1996.
Jensen was the recipient of numerous awards for scholarly achievements throughout his career. He also served as the President of the <a href="Centre%20de%20Guillaume%20IX">Centre de Guillaume IX</a>, a center for research in <a href="Troubadour">Troubadour</a> studies, and was a member of the editorial board of <a href="http%3A//www.worldcat.org/title/semasia/oclc/2706069">Semasia</a> (a <a href="Romance%20Languages">romance</a> <a href="philology">philology</a> publication). 
He was also an avid <a href="mountaineer">mountaineer</a> who summitted hundreds of peaks in <a href="Canada">Canada</a>, <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a>, <a href="Morocco">Morocco</a>, <a href="Europe">Europe</a> and the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>, and he climbed all fifty three of <a href="List%20of%20Colorado%20fourteeners">Colorado's 14,000-foot peaks</a> within two summers. He continued to <a href="Hiking">hike</a> regularly up until his death in September 2008, in <a href="Boulder%20Colorado">Boulder, Colorado</a>, at the age of 82.
Education.
Middle school, a private school in <a href="Allingaabro">Allingaabro</a>, <a href="Denmark">Denmark</a>
High school studies at <a href="Randers%20Stattskole">Randers Stattskole</a> in <a href="Randers">Randers</a>, <a href="Denmark">Denmark</a>, graduating in June, 1945
<a href="University%20of%20Copenhagen">University of Copenhagen</a>, <a href="Denmark">Denmark</a>, 1949 (<a href="B.A.">B.A.</a>)
<a href="University%20of%20Grenoble">Université de Grenoble</a>, <a href="France">France</a>, 1950, Certificat de Grammaire et de Philologie Françaises
<a href="University%20of%20Copenhagen">University of Copenhagen</a>, <a href="Denmark">Denmark</a>, 1953, M.A. (with distinction) with <a href="College%20major">major</a> in <a href="French%20Language">French</a> and a <a href="Minor%20%28academic%29">minor</a> in <a href="English%20Language">English</a>
<a href="University%20of%20Salamanca">University of Salamanca</a>, <a href="Spain">Spain</a>, 1955, Diplomado de Filologia Hispánica
<a href="UCLA">U.C.L.A.</a>, <a href="California">California</a>, <a href="United%20States">U.S.A.</a>1961, Ph.D. in <a href="Romance%20languages">Romance Languages</a> and Literatures, with major emphasis on <a href="Philology">Philology</a> (<a href="French%20Language">French</a>, <a href="Spanish%20Language">Spanish</a>, <a href="Italian%20Language">Italian</a>)
Professional career.
<a href="University%20of%20Washington%20at%20Seattle">University of Washington at Seattle</a>, 1956–57, <a href="Assistant%20professor%23Assistant%20professor">Teaching Assistant</a>, Department of <a href="Romance%20Languages">Romance Languages</a>.
<a href="UCLA">U.C.L.A</a>, 1957-60, <a href="Assistant%20professor%23Assistant%20professor">Teaching Assistant</a>, Department of <a href="French%20Language">French</a>.
<a href="Katedralskole">Katedralskole</a>, <a href="Nyk%C3%B8bing%20Falster">Nykøbing (Falster)</a>, <a href="Denmark">Denmark</a>, 1960-1961, <a href="Teacher">Acting Instructor</a> in <a href="French%20Language">French</a> and <a href="English%20Language">English</a>.
<a href="University%20of%20Calgary">University of Calgary</a>, 1961-64, <a href="Assistant%20professor%23Assistant%20professor">Assistant Professor</a> of <a href="Modern%20Languages">Modern Languages</a>.
<a href="UCLA">U.C.L.A.</a>, 1964-67, <a href="Assistant%20professor%23Assistant%20professor">Assistant Professor</a> of <a href="French%20Language">French</a> and <a href="Romance%20Languages">Romance</a> <a href="Philology">Philology</a>.
<a href="University%20of%20Colorado%20at%20Boulder">University of Colorado at Boulder</a>, 1967-73, <a href="Associate%20professor%23Tenured%20and%20tenure-track%20positions">Associate Professor</a> of <a href="French%20Language">French</a> and <a href="Linguistics">Linguistics</a>.
<a href="University%20of%20Colorado%20at%20Boulder">University of Colorado at Boulder</a>, 1973-77, <a href="Professorship">Professor</a> of <a href="French%20Language">French</a> and <a href="Linguistics">Linguistics</a>.
<a href="University%20of%20Colorado%20at%20Boulder">University of Colorado at Boulder</a>, 1977-1996, <a href="Professorship">Professor</a> of <a href="French%20Language">French</a>.
Publications.
Books.
1. "The Italian Verb, A Morphological Study", University of North Carolina Press, Studies in the Romance Languages and Literatures, No. 107, 1971. 97 pp.
2. "From Vulgar Latin to Old Provençal". University of North Carolina Press, Studies in the Romance Languages and Literatures, No. 120, 1972. 97 pp.
3. F. Jensen and T. Lathrop: "The Syntax of the Old Spanish Subjunctive". The Hague: Mouton Publishers, Janua Linguarum Series, 1973. 92 pp.
4. "The Syntax of the Old French Subjunctive". The Hague: Mouton Publishers, Janua Lunguarum Series,1974. 134 pp.
5. "The Old Provençal Noun and Adjective Declension". Odense University Press, Études romanes de l'Université d'Odense, Vol. 9, 1976. 177 pp.
6. "The Earliest Portuguese Lyrics". Odense University Press, Études romanes de l'Université d'Odense, Vol. 11, 1978. 308 pp.
7. "Provençal Philology and the Poetry of Guillaume of Poitiers". Odense University Press, Études romanes de l'Université d'Odense, Vol. 13, 1983. 374 pp.
8. "The Poetry of the Sicilian School". New York and London: Garland Publishing, Inc., Garland Library of Medieval Literature, Series A, Vol. 22, 1986. I-LXXIII. 250pp
9. "The Syntax of Medieval Occitan". Tübingen/West Germany: Max Niemeyer Verlag, "Beihefte zur Zeitschirft für romanische Philologie", Vol. 208, 1986. I-VII. 431 pp.
10. "Old French and Comparative Gallo-Romance Syntax". Tübingen/West Germany: Max Niemeyer Verlag, "Beihefte zur Zeitschirft für romanische Philologie", Vol. 232, 1990. I-XI. 590 pp.
11. "Medieval Galician-Portuguese Poetry. An Anthology". New York and London: Garland Publishing, Inc., Garland Library of Medieval Literature, Series A, Vol. 87 1992. I-CXXXVIII. 624 pp. (see <a href="http%3A//journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract%3FfromPage%3Donline%26amp%3Baid%3D7688592">review</a>)
12. "Syntaxe de l'ancien occitan". Tübingen/West Germany: Max Niemeyer Verlag, "Beihefte zur Zeitschift für romanische Philologie", Vol. 257, 1994. 404 pp.
13. "Tuscan Poetry of the Duecento". New York and London: Garland Publishing, Inc., Garland Library of Medieval Literature, Series A, Vol. 99, 1994, I-XLV, 335 pp.
14. "Troubadour Lyrics. A Bilingual Anthology". New York: Peter Lang Publishing, Studies in the Humanities, vol. 39, 1998, 593 pp.
15. "A Comparative Study of Romance". New York: Peter Lang Publishing, Studies in the Humanities, vol. 46, 1999, 446 pp.
16. "La Vie de Saint Eustace. Introduction to Old French. Philological Commentary by Frede Jensen". Edition and Introduction by Tom Lathrop. Newark/Delaware: LinguaText, Ltd., 2000, 208 pp.
17. "The language of the eleventh century "Vie de St. Alexis"". Edition by Tom Lathrop. Newark/Delaware: LinguaText, Ltd., 2003, 367 pp.
